 UPDATE      2NDUPDATE
      CoxNet Cox News Service budget
      FOR WEDNESDAY, June 14, 2000
      c. 2000 Cox News Service

   For questions, please call 404-526-5456.

   Photo and graphics information and editors' names can be found
at the end of this budget.

   Eds. Adds: WORKERS, COKE, COX-RADIO, PICNIC, BRAZILL, KIDSJAIL

   INTERNATIONAL

   ASSAD-FUNERAL _ DAMASCUS, Syria _ World leaders, but few from
outside the Middle East, bid farewell Tuesday to late Syrian
President Hafez Assad. Syria's price for Assad's defiant defense of
Arab pride is isolation, as evidenced in the paucity of Western
leaders here Tuesday, compared to the number that flocked to King
Hussein's funeral 16 months

   ago. Developing.(Kaplow, Cox News Service). 30.

   EDS: Expected to move on NYT Wire by 5:30 p.m. EDT.

   WITH

   SYRIA-JEWS _ DAMASCUS, Syria _ Thousands have left, but there
are still about 100 Jews in Syria. This week, they are praying
every morning for Hafez Assad to be blessed and for God to help
guide his son Bashar. Assad had helped many Syrian minorities _
Christians, Alawites _ and the Jewish community say they will miss
him. (Kaplow, Cox News Service).

   EDS: Expected to move on NYT Wire by 5:30 p.m. EDT.

   MEXICO-ELECTIONS _ WASHINGTON _ Three weeks before a historic
presidential election in Mexico, concerns are apparently rising
among international observers as to whether it will be a fair
election. (Michals, Cox News Service). 15.

   EDs: Expected to move on NYT wire by 6 p.m. EDT in (i)
International and (w) Washington categories.

   NATIONAL

   GORE-PROSPERITY _ NEW YORK _ Vice President Al Gore makes what
is being billed as a ``major'' policy address on ``progress and
prosperity.'' The speech is seen as an attempt by the vice
president, who is lagging slightly in polls against his GOP rival,
to take more credit for the nation's prolonged economic surge.
(Shepard, Cox News Service). 28.

   EDs: Moving on NYT wire in (p) politics category.

   DNATESTING _ WASHINGTON _ Senate Judiciary Committee Tuesday
hears testimony from experts on the use of post-conviction DNA
testing. The hearing comes amid increasing examples of DNA being
used to clear people wrongly convicted of crimes. (O'Dell, Cox News
Service).

   EDs: Moving on the NYT wire in (w) Washington category.

   HORNETS _ CHARLOTTE - Is Ray Wooldridge coming today? Or will
the Atlanta millionaire who is part owner of the Charlotte Hornets
be a no-show, again, for a City Hall meeting to discuss a new
downtown arena for the struggling NBA franchise? In recent weeks,
Wooldridge has been the Hornets' face man pitching what's so far
been much-scorned proposals for financing the $160 million arena.
First, he proposed that local government finance all of the cost;
then he said the Hornets would be willing to chip in a third of the
cost. A look at the 56-year-old Wooldridge who, despite his low
profile in Altanta business and professional sports, has surpassed
Hornets controversial majority owner George Shinn as the guy
Charlotte is trying to figure out. (Burritt, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution).

   WAN: Location Atlanta, category National

   COASTAL _ WASHINGTON _ Coastal communities nationwide should
follow Florida's example and demonstrate to the federal government
an economic need to protect beaches and shores, a coastal group was
told Tuesday. (Lipman, Cox News Service). 12.

   LEWIS-FALLOUT _ ATLANTA _ Trying to reach jurors in the Buckhead
stabbings case. Also, in an interview, former defendants Joseph
Sweeting and Reginald Oakley talk about how they felt being charged
and what they thought about Ray Lewis becoming a witness for the
prosecution. The two men say Lewis lied on the stand and they also
condemned the linebacker for not running to their aid as they say
they were attacked. Oakley and Sweeting partied at the Gold Club
into the early morning hours after their acquittals. (Rankin,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 18.

   POL-TICKER _ A brief roundup of the day's campaign events,
pulled from Cox staff and wire reports. (Cox News Service) ETA: 6
p.m.

   TOBACCO _ Day two of tobacco execs testifying to avoid a huge
damage award. (Bennett, Palm Beach Post)

   BRAZILL_ First appearance for Nate Brazill, just indicted as an
adult for first degree murder in the fatal shooting of Barry Grunow
and aggravated assault with a firearm for waving the gun at another
teacher. (Spencer, Palm Beach Post)

   WITH

   KIDSJAIL _ Behind a powder blue steel door on the 12th floor of
the jail, Nathaniel Brazill joins 59 other kids charged with adult
crimes. The kids, all awaiting trial for felonies, live in a stark
environment of walk-in closet sized cells where they are allowed
few privileges. They can take a paper-back book, a pencil and two
sheets of paper. After in-jail school, they can watch G-rated
movies such as Ghostbusters and Dante's Peak and the only violence
they see is on the networks. Their favorite programs are Cops,
America's Most Wanted and the nightly news. (Douthat, Palm Beach
Post).

   OPED/EDITORIAL

   TEEPEN-COLUMN _ More whites use drugs but more blacks go to
prison for drug offenses. When will we address this issue? (Teepen,
Cox News Service.) MOVED MONDAY.

   KLEINBERG-COLUMN _ The federal government must give the tools to
the Coast Guard to fight the war it is chartered to do: to protect
our coasts. The Congress thinks nothing of pouring billions of
dollars into our other military branches involving foreign
incursions; how about something that is leeching our shores?
(Kleinberg, Cox News Service.) MOVED MONDAY.

   SCHUETT-COLUMN _ GIBSONBURG, Ohio _ My friend Dan's grandmother
had a system for determining ahead of time what kind of a day she
was going to have. Alternate days were ``good'' an. But both sides
continue to work at a settlement, which may lead the judge in the
case to OK another extension. (Unger, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   COX-RADIO _Cox Radio's complicated $280 million manuever to buy
another hot radio station in Atlanta comes in a super lucrative
market that has yet to

   consolidate the way most of the nation's big radio markets have.
But a top executive with the country's largest station owner
predicts more big station sales that will leave the Atlanta market
with just three big station owners. (Kempner, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   WORKERS _ Ping pong, anyone? The bid for workers is so fierce
that employers are using all sorts of enticements to get and keep
workers: BMWs,concierge services, free lunches, on-site massages,
$5,000 referral bonuses, $100,000 relocation packages and yes, even
game rooms with ping pong tables. And if that doesn't work, they're
also bringing workers in from overseas and ``growing'' their own.
The Boys & Girls Club is targeting computer-savvy kids to become
junior staff members. It's not just tech companies in need of
technical experts . It's law firms like Alston & Bird and pr
agencies. Eight out of 10 employers responding to the latest AJC
poll said they have tech workers and an equally high percentage say
they plan to spend more on such workers in the next two years.
(Joyner, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   MONEYTALK _ Personal finance advice. This week: Paying off
student loans. (Ezell, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). MOVED.

   WEB-VAN _ ATLANTA _ A look at WebVan and how it is doing in the
early days of its operation in Atlanta. Early success has also
brought early problems such as finding drivers, finding trucks and
literally finding time to deliver groceries to waiting customers.
(Katz, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 18.

   SMART-SHIRT _ ATLANTA _ The Georgia Tech ``smart shirt,'' which
can measure human body characteristics continuously, may be headed
for new medical uses through a new licensing agreement with a New
York firm. The company, SensaTex, Inc., plans to use the shirt
technology to produce garments that patients can wear and
discreetly relay information to physicians and nurses about heart
function, respiratiion, temperature and other measures of
well-being. (Holsendolph, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 18.

   COXNET WHEELS PAGE

   EDs: This is the CoxNet WHEELS page for the current week. This
layout is available now.

   COXNET WHEELS 0610: 200O KIA SPECTRA _ Driveability and pricing
make for a nice package for the Kia Spectra; good gas mileage
doesn't hurt, either. (DeVault, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) Art
includes a 4-column color photo of the 2000 Kia Spectra and a
1-column photo of the car's dash.

   WITH

   AT A GLANCE _ Fact box previewing the 2000 Kia Spectra.

   THE MECHANIC _ Boosting mileage can ease the sting of higher
gasoline prices. (Carter, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). Includes
1-column color photograph of columnist.

   SENTRA-REVIEW _ A review of the Nissan Sentra. (DeVault, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 18. MOVED.

   LIFESTYLE

   BAPTISTS-MAIN_ ORLANDO _ Daily coverage of the Southern Baptist
Convention, meeting this week in Orlando. On Tuesday they will
elect a new president, probably James Merrit, pastor of First
Baptist Snelof chips and hot dogs cooked on the park grill. In
reality, today's family actually may be blessed beyond Grandma's
imagination. Just one quick trip through the supermarket or deli
and Mom or Dad can pick up a grab-and-go picnic, prepped, cooked
and ready to eat _ and instantly customized to satisfy individual
family tastes. (Dayton Daily News)

   FASHION

   TURTLENECKS _ So, it may be too hot here to take advantage of
this, but the buzz in the fashion world for men is that Samuel L.
Jackson will make turtlenecks and long leather jackets hip again.
Who you talkin 'bout? (Wizda, Austin American-Statesman). 12-15.
WITH PHOTOS (from new and old ``Shaft'' movies). 12-15.

   SCIENCE-MEDICINE

   PSYCHOLOGY-TODAY _ Dr. Hap LeCrone's weekly psychology column.
This week: Follow up discussion of Generalized Anxiety Disorder.
(LeCrone, Waco Tribune-Herald). MOVED.

   HOME AND GARDEN

   GARDENING-LIFE _ A gardening column by Lee May. This week: Lee
May writes about what it's like to be a multi-tasker. Women have
long had the trick down pat, he says, but Lee has turned to the
garden for inspiration. ``Now, as I lurch toward the world of
multiple tasks, I turn to the garden for instruction in getting
there. And I find much.'' There's beautiful wisteria, columbine and
nandina to name just a few of the mighty garden doers. Column also
mentions that May will return to writing weekly. (May, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   Eds: Embargoed for Thursday, June 15.

   FOXGLOVES _ Robert Keller has a huge respect for plants, but the
ones he really looks up to are his foxgloves _ all 6-plus feet of
them. The DeKalb County resident grows some 300 of them each spring
with blooms ranging from creamy white to pale pink to deep purple.
For six weeks, his garden puts on such a show that traffic slows
past his house, with many drivers pausing to ask his
secret.(Flanders, Atlanta Journal-Constitution.)

   Eds: Embargoed for Thursday, June 15.

   WATERBAN-ADVICE _ Walter Reeves says all is not lost with the
15-county watering ban. He shares advice for plants, trees, shrubs
and lawns. Includes Web sites for daily drough updates on watering
ban. (Reeves, Atlanta Journal-Constitution freelancer; not for use
by NYTNS clients.)

   Eds: Embargoed for Thursday, June 15.

   VERBENA _ Plant profile: Verbena bonariensis; sometimes called
``verbena-on-a-stick,'' this Southern beauty is easy to grow and
will thrive as long as it receives full sun and normal garden soil.
(Tate, Atlanta Journal-Constitution freelancer; not for use by
NYTNS clients.)

   Eds: Embargoed for Thursday, June 15.

   FOOD

   PICNICS _ At the mention of a family picnic, the archetypal
Grandma would fry some chicken, make a bowl of potato salad and
bake a pie. In today's time-challenged world the brood is lucky to
get a bag of chips and hot dogs cooked on the park grill. In
reality, today's family actually may be blessed beyond Grandma's
imagination. Just one quick trip through the supermarket or deli
and Mom or Dad can pick up a grab-and-go picnic, prepped, cooked
and ready to eat _ and instantly customized to satisfy individual
family tastes. (Dayton Daily News). 17. WITH PHOTOS.

   WITH

   PICNICS-READY-TO-EAT _ It is tempting to pick up the
ready-to-eat makings of an epicurean picnic at the store. And it
couldn't be easier. (Dayton Daily News). 16. WITH PHOTOS.

   COUNTRY-FOOD _ Whiskey, Red Meat, Gravy & Pie. Strum another
chord Terry and sing it: Life's not about dogs and trucks and
buddies in jail. It's about those things man cannot deny: whiskey,
red meat, gravy and pie. (Lake Austin Spa's Terry Conlan has
figured out lower fat versions of these things that are really
good. Coffee-crusted sirloin with jalapeno redeye gravy, garlic
mashed potatoes, sweet potato bourbon pie.) We'll do this in
country music style. (Crider, Austin American-Statesman). WITH
PHOTOS.

   WINE _ Mark Fisher's wine column looks at screw-tops on $135
bottles of wine and neon-color labels on German wines. (Fisher,
Dayton Daiuly News). 15. WITH PHOTO.

   ENTERTAINMENT-ARTS

   ROCKWELL _ WASHINGTON _ The Corcoran Gallery of Art previews the
comprehensive exhibit of the works of Norman Rockwell, spanning the
60-year career of an American art legend, that made an earlier stop
in Atlanta. (Dart, Cox News Service). 20.

   SPORTS

   GOLF

   GLF-OPEN-MICKELSON _ Phil Mickelson was close to winning last
year's U.S. Open at Pinehurst before losing to Payne Stewart.
Mickelson has won three times this sason and is hoping to shank the
image of being the best golfer yet to win a major title. (Sheeley,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 25.

   BASKETBALL

   HORNETS _ CHARLOTTE - Is Ray Wooldridge coming today? Or will
the Atlanta millionaire who is part owner of the Charlotte Hornets
be a no-show, again, for a City Hall meeting to discuss a new
downtown arena for the struggling NBA franchise? In recent weeks,
Wooldridge has been the Hornets' face man pitching what's so far
been much-scorned proposals for financing the $160 million arena.
First, he proposed that local government finance all of the cost;
then he said the Hornets would be willing to chip in a third of the
cost. A look at the 56-year-old Wooldridge who, despite his low
profile in Altanta business and professional sports, has surpassed
Hornets controversial majority owner George Shinn as the guy
Charlotte is trying to figure out. (Burritt, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution).

   EDs: Moving on NYT wire in (a) General News and (s) Sports
categories.

   BASEBALL

   BBN-FURCALL _ Checking Rafael Furcal and the age fiasco. Is he
19 or 22? Will check with agent, call MLB and check on underage
drinking charge. (Frias, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 14.

   COXNET BUDGET INFORMATION

   This budget moves at 10 a.m., 2 p.m. and 6 p.m. EST and
afterwards as necessary based on news developments. If stories will
move after 8 p.m., an ETA will be given. All times are Eastern
unless otherwise noted.

   INTERNET LINKS

   For research purposes, or to publish in your paper for readers
who'd like more information, Internet links to some of the stories
on this budget are available daily on the Cox Intranet at
http://web.coxnews.net/NRS/NTAGS/NTAGWEEK.HTM

   PHOTOS, LAYOUTS and GRAPHICS Features, business and op-ed
material on this budget is available exclusively through the Budget
Tool, which brings into your database the story with attached
layout and graphics.

   Regarding all other material: Stories that have photos, graphics
or page layouts will be posted on the Cox Server in folders
matching the category and slug. (Exception: Bureau photos are
available only through the Atlanta Location, Washington Bureau
desk, slugged to match the story.) Pages marked as CoxNet pages are
also available through Locations in the WAN desk of the AJC's
database.

   FEATURES MATERIAL

   So specialty editors can focus on one day's budget, CoxNet
produces themed features budgets each day. Here is the schedule:

   Monday for Tuesday: Technology

   TODAY: Automotive, personal finance and home & garden

   Wednesday for Thursday: Food, CD reviews, video reviews

   Thursday for Friday: Movie reviews, travel, books and fashion

   Friday for Saturday: Religion and science & health

   HOW TO REACH US

   Questions should be directed to CoxNet, the Cox News Service, in
Atlanta at 800-950-3739 or 404-526-5456. We are staffed 8 a.m. to
10 p.m. Monday-Friday, and 1-10 p.m. on weekends and holidays.

   The day news editor is Tom Oder, 404-526-5887,
toder(at)coxnews.com.

   The night news editor is Todd C. Duncan, 404-582-7282,
tduncan(at)coxnews.com.

   Cox Washington Bureau:

   News editor Art Dalglish, 202-887-8338, artd(at)coxnews.com

   Foreign editor Rick Christie, 202-887-8316, rickc(at)coxnews.com

   Bureau chief Andy Alexander, 202-887-8334, andya(at)coxnews.com

   Photo Editor Rick McKay 202-887-8348, rickm(at)coxnews.com

   PICNICS _ At the mention of a family picnic, the archetypal
Grandma would fry some chicken, make a bowl of potato salad and
bake a pie. In today's time-challenged world the brood is lucky to
get a bag of chips and hot dogs cooked on the park grill. In
reality, today's family actually may be blessed beyond Grandma's
imagination. Just one quick trip through the supermarket or deli
and Mom or Dad can pick up a grab-and-go picnic, prepped, cooked
and ready to eat _ and instantly customized to satisfy individual
family tastes. (Dayton Daily News). 17. WITH PHOTOS.

   BASKETBALL

   HORNETS _ CHARLOTTE - Is Ray Wooldridge coming today? Or will
the Atlanta millionaire who is part owner of the Charlotte Hornets
be a no-show, again, for a City Hall meeting to discuss a new
downtown arena for the struggling NBA franchise? In recent weeks,
Wooldridge has been the Hornets' face man pitching what's so far
been much-scorned proposals for financing the $160 million arena.
First, he proposed that local government finance all of the cost;
then he said the Hornets would be willing to chip in a third of the
cost. A look at the 56-year-old Wooldridge who, despite his low
profile in Altanta business and professional sports, has surpassed
Hornets controversial majority owner George Shinn as the guy
Charlotte is trying to figure out. (Burritt, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution).
